Award.AwardTitle: Studies in Free Probability and Operator Algebras
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main themes of the project are the analytic side of free probability and almost-normal operators modulo the Hilbert-Schmidt class. This will involve on the one hand further study of the "free Riemann sphere," a highly noncommutative analogue of the Riemann sphere, and of corresponding highly noncommutative functions. On the other hand, the almost-normal operator questions are related to the study of certain Banach algebras of operators on Hilbert space and their K-theory. The operator theory part of the project also has connections to noncommutative probability, since the operator algebras considered appear naturally in noncommutative potential theory and the analogue of Fisher information in free probability involves, in the simplest cases, almost-normal operators.

Free probability is a probability framework adapted to deal with random variables that exhibit the highest degree of noncommutativity. The theory has important connections with operator algebra theory, with random matrix theory, and with certain topics in combinatorics. Studies in free probability often benefit from these connections and, in return, may be of interest in these other fields. In particular, users of random matrices in certain models of multiuser wireless communications and in certain physics models have found the free probability approach to random matrices useful.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Free probability is the noncommutative  probability framework where the noncommutativity is the highest : not only because the random variables of the theory are quantum mechanical observables, but also because the free independence relation around which it is built, produces additional noncommutativity. Free probability appears asymptotically in the behavior of important classes of random matrices as well as in free products of operator algebras, like the von Neumann algebras of free groups. The broader impact of studies in free probability comes from models in physics and engineering which are based on random matrices which can be handled with free probability techniques. This is the case, for instance, of certain random matrix models of multiuser telecommunication systems. 

 In 2013, I found that free probability has a natural extension to a more general theory where the random variables are structured in two groups, one of left variables and one of right variables, which do not commute in general , and for which there is a notion of bi-free independence, which generalizes free independence. One main focus of the research I carried out under this award, in a series of papers, were first steps in the development of the emerging bi-free probability, finding analytic formulae for the simplest cases of bi-free convolution operations, arising from addition, multiplication and their combination as well as the Ando max operation. Other researchers, including several young mathematicians have become interested in bi-free probability and the exploration has been moving fast. This has had a certain development of human resources impact.

 In certain free probability questions, finite rank commutators appear naturally, which also happens, for instance, in bi-free probability, among left and right variables of bi-free Gaussian systems. This, in conjunction with technical aspects of recent noncommutative geometry work of Alain Connes, have motivated a new direction, connecting with my earlier work on normed ideal perturbations of Hilbert space operators.While the earlier work studied a numerical invariant measuring the obstruction to quasicentral approximate units relative to the normed ideal, the recent realization is that there is more structure involved in these questions, which is present in the commutant modulo a normed ideal, of an n-tuple of  selfadjoint operators. The research under the present award has shown that this is a more general phenomenon than initially expected. These commutants mod normed ideals are Banach algebras that are often closer to C*-algebras than expected, they often have Calkin algebras which are C*-algebras or are isomorphic to C*-algebras and there are duality results and unique predual results like in the case of some basic C8-algebras. On the other hand I have been able to obtain K-theory results about these algebras, which exhibit several new phenomena pointing to differences with the basic C*-algebras. This has resulted in several papers on the arXiv or already published. Overall, these commutants mod normed ideals, which are closer to the Atiyah point of view of abstract elliptic operators in the K-theory of operator algebras, seem to have better features technically than working inside the algebra of operators mod a normed ideal. An intellectual merit of this research is to have identified a new class of operator algebras with strong connections to normed ideal peturbations of Hilbert space operators.

 At UC Berkeley I have continued running the Probabilistic Operator Algebra Seminar and I have also continued organizing conferences in this area. The two graduate students I have been supervising, Adam Merberg and Weihua Liu have completed their Ph D during this period. I have also been the senior scientist for NSF postdoctoral fellow Brent Nelson at UC Berkeley, who works on questions around free probability.
